description: An annual herb in the family Apiaceae. All parts of the plant are edible, but the fresh leaves and the dried seeds (as a spice) are the parts most traditionally used in cooking.
origin: Southern Europe, Northern Africa, Southwestern Asia
seasons: Year-round (can be grown in various climates, often in pots)
healthBenefits: Rich in Vitamin K, important for blood clotting and bone health.
Good source of Vitamin A and Vitamin C, supporting vision and immunity.
Contains antioxidants that may help lower inflammation.
Traditionally used to aid digestion and as a flavoring agent.

potentialAllergies.name: Cilantro Aversion/Sensitivity
potentialAllergies.details: A significant portion of the population perceives cilantro leaves as having a soapy taste due to genetic factors (OR6A2 gene). This is not an allergy but a taste perception.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Cool-season herb, prone to bolting (flowering) in hot weather. Sow seeds directly in spring or fall.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil. pH 6.0-7.0. Full sun to partial shade.
3. Spacing: Sow seeds 1/4-1/2 inch deep. Thin seedlings if needed.
4. Watering: Keep soil consistently moist, especially during germination and active growth.
5. Harvesting: Harvest outer leaves when plants are 4-6 inches tall. Pinching back tips encourages bushier growth. Seeds (coriander spice) are harvested when plant flowers and seed heads turn brown.
growthDuration: Leaves ready for harvest in 4-6 weeks from sowing.
sustainabilityTips: Store fresh coriander leaves with stems in a jar of water in the refrigerator, covered loosely with a plastic bag, or wrap in a damp paper towel.
Use both leaves and tender stems.
Can be chopped and frozen in ice cube trays with water or oil for later use.
carbonFootprintInfo: Very low, especially when home-grown or locally sourced (0.1-0.3 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Coriander (Cilantro) Chutney
staticRecipes.description: A vibrant and flavorful Indian green chutney, perfect as a dip or accompaniment.
ingredients: 1-2 green chilies, chopped (adjust to spice preference)
steps: Wash coriander and mint leaves thoroughly.
Combine all ingredients (coriander, mint, green chilies, ginger, lemon juice, salt, and a little water) in a blender.
Blend until smooth, adding more water tablespoon by tablespoon if needed to achieve desired consistency. Be careful not to make it too runny.
Taste and adjust salt or lemon juice if necessary.
Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to a week. Serve with snacks, sandwiches, or Indian meals.

staticRecipes.name: Cilantro-Lime Rice
staticRecipes.description: A fragrant and zesty rice dish, a popular side for Mexican or Southwestern meals.
steps: Cook rice according to package directions using water or broth. (Typically, bring liquid to a boil, add rice, cover, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until liquid is absorbed).
While rice is cooking or once done, heat olive oil/butter in a small skillet if using garlic. Sauté minced garlic for 30 seconds until fragrant. Remove from heat.
Once rice is cooked, fluff it with a fork. Add chopped cilantro, lime juice, sautéed garlic (if using), and salt to taste.
Stir gently to combine all ingredients thoroughly.
Serve warm as a side dish.

staticRecipes.name: Garnish with Fresh Coriander
staticRecipes.description: Using fresh coriander leaves as a vibrant garnish for various dishes.
ingredients: Fresh coriander leaves (cilantro), chopped or whole
steps: Wash fresh coriander leaves thoroughly and pat dry.
For a fine garnish, chop the leaves. For a more rustic look, use whole leaves or sprigs.
Sprinkle generously over curries, dals, soups, salads, tacos, stir-fries, or any dish just before serving.
Coriander adds a fresh, bright flavor and visual appeal.

uses: Culinary herb (fresh leaves - cilantro - used as garnish and flavoring in salads, salsas, curries, soups, chutneys, tacos)
Spice (dried seeds - coriander - used whole or ground in curries, spice blends, sausages, pickling, baking)
Roots used in some cuisines (e.g., Thai)

climaticRequirements.temperature: Cool season herb for leaf (cilantro) production, optimal 15-22°C. Tolerates warmer temperatures for seed (coriander) production but bolts quickly. Sensitive to frost.
climaticRequirements.rainfall: Prefers consistent moisture, around 400-600 mm during growing season or regular irrigation. Well-drained soil is crucial to prevent root rot.
climaticRequirements.altitude: Can be grown from sea level to moderate altitudes, typically up to 2000m.

soilPreferences: Well-drained, fertile, loamy soil rich in organic matter. Prefers slightly acidic to neutral pH (6.0-7.5).
irrigationWaterNeeds: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, especially during germination and active leaf growth. Water stress can lead to premature bolting (flowering). Drip irrigation or light overhead watering is suitable.
plantingHarvestCycles: Propagated by seeds. For cilantro (leaves): sow seeds directly in succession every 2-3 weeks from early spring to early autumn. Harvest outer leaves once plants are 4-6 inches tall. For coriander (seeds): plant in spring. Seeds mature when plants turn brown and seed heads are dry, typically 90-120 days after sowing. Harvest by cutting entire plants/seed heads.
pestDiseaseManagement: Pests: Aphids, armyworms, cutworms, leafhoppers. Diseases: Powdery mildew, bacterial leaf spot, Fusarium wilt, stem gall. Management includes crop rotation, good air circulation, avoiding overhead watering in humid conditions, using disease-free seeds, and organic pest controls.
postHarvestHandling: Cilantro leaves: Highly perishable. Harvest early in the day. Store in the refrigerator with stems in water, covered loosely, or wrapped in a damp paper towel for a few days. Coriander seeds: Harvest seed heads when dry, complete drying on trays or by hanging. Thresh to separate seeds, then clean and store in an airtight container in a cool, dark place.
marketValueGlobalDemand: High global demand for both fresh cilantro leaves and dried coriander seeds. Essential in many international cuisines (Mexican, Indian, Southeast Asian, Middle Eastern). Coriander seed is a major internationally traded spice. Cilantro is primarily traded fresh or as processed paste.
